message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. B cell differentiation and proliferation occur in the germinal center, which is located in the follicle of the lymph node. In the image, the follicle is labeled as section 3, thus the correct answer is (B). Sections 1 and 5 are lymphoid sinuses, while section 4 is a medullary cord.

We do not have access to the image referenced in the question, but we can provide a general explanation. B cell differentiation and proliferation typically occur in the germinal center of lymph nodes, which is located in section 3. This is where B cells undergo somatic hypermutation, affinity maturation, and class switching to produce high-affinity antibodies specific to the antigen presented by the CD4+ T helper cell. Therefore, the correct answer is (B).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. B cell differentiation and proliferation occur in section 3, the germinal center. This is where B cells undergo somatic hypermutation and class switching, leading to the production of high-affinity antibodies.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The process described in the question is the immune response, specifically the activation of B cells by T helper cells. In a lymph node, B cell differentiation and proliferation occur in the germinal center, which is located in section 3 of the lymph node.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The image shows a typical structure of a lymph node, with section #3 being the germinal center where B cell differentiation and proliferation occur in response to the antigen presented by CD4+ T helper cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The image provided shows a labeled diagram of a lymph node with different numbered sections. B cell differentiation and proliferation most likely occur in section 3, also known as the germinal center, where B cells undergo somatic hypermutation, class switching, and differentiation into antibody-producing plasma cells.
We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. B cell differentiation and proliferation occur in the germinal center, which is located in section 3 of the lymph node.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The image provided shows different sections of a lymph node, including the follicle, paracortex, and medulla. B cell differentiation and proliferation most likely occur in the follicle, which is section 3 in the image. Antigen-presenting cells present antigens to CD4+ T helper cells in the paracortex, but B cell differentiation and proliferation occur in the follicle.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. B cell differentiation and proliferation usually occur in the germinal center of the lymph node, which is located in section 3 of the lymph node shown in the image. This is where the B cells undergo somatic hypermutation and class switching to produce high-affinity antibodies.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The image provided shows the different anatomical sections of the lymph node, including the paracortex (section 3). The paracortex is where T cells and B cells interact, and B cell differentiation and proliferation occur in response to antigen presentation by CD4+ T helper cells.
